message: #WatchLive this morning's swearing in of the Congressional Black Caucus 115th Congress cbcfinc.org/live @OfficialCBC

“I’m relieved that Congressional Republicans reversed their decision to eliminate the Office of Congressional Ethics. With all of the challenges that America faces today, I am deeply concerned that this was the first action that was being considered in the 115th Congress. I hope this is not indicative of the direction Congress is headed over the next two years.”

Today I stood with my colleagues in the Congressional Black Caucus to speak out against Republican efforts to repeal the Affordable Care Act and ask the Senate to reject the nomination of Jeff Sessions for U.S. attorney general.
Today, I joined more than 150 House Democrats in asking for an independent commission to investigate Russia’s interference in the 2016 election.
Today is National Law Enforcement Appreciation Day. Thank you to all the men and women in blue who risk their lives to serve & protect.  #NationalLawEnforcementAppreciationDay
Today I stood with my Dem colleagues on the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence to push for a bipartisan, independent probe into Russia's interference in the 2016 election.
Happening Now: Headed down to the House Floor to vote AGAINST repealing the Affordable Care Act. I will do all I can to  stand up against Republican attempts to dismantle this important legislation.

The peaceful transfer of power from one democratically elected President to another is distinctively American and the bedrock of our democracy. Today we witnessed this occur for the 44th time in our nation's history.  Despite our political divisions, as President Obama recently said, we are all on the same team. As a public servant, I will continue to look for ways to keep our country moving forward, not backwards, and be vigilant in my responsibility as a Member of a co-equal branch of government to make sure the new administration is checked and balanced appropriately.
Need help with a federal agency? My staff will be holding office hours in your neighborhood today! I encourage you to stop by and see how we can help you!

#TBT to 6 months ago when I welcomed this beautiful Syrian refugee family to their new home here in Indianapolis!  Banning or delaying asylum for refugee families would weaken our national security and undermine our country’s humanitarian efforts around the world. #RefugeesWelcome

This Valentine’s Day, let's show Hoosier veterans that their sacrifices and service to our country will never be forgotten. Drop off or mail a Valentine's Day card for a veteran to my Indianapolis office:  300 E Fall Creek Pkwy. N. Dr. Suite 300 Indianapolis, IN 46205
All are welcome in my office. That's the American way. #RefugeesWelcome

This resolution raises awareness for the continued need for education, research and treatment for patients and families affected by these conditions.

In both Democratic and Republican Administrations, I have stood against any effort to cut projects that create jobs and grow the economy in Indianapolis. These projects are nonpartisan and have always enjoyed support from elected officials from both parties.   Today, I was concerned to see the President presented a budget that would eliminate federal funds for the Red Line, which is the backbone of our city’s growing transit system. As in the past, I hope to come together with my Republican colleagues across the state to support the funding of this project that will create jobs and expand our infrastructure.  Learn more about the Red Line -> https://www.indygo.net/redline/

This morning, the House Intelligence Committee will be holding its first public, non-classified hearing on the Russia Investigation. FBI Director Comey and NSA Director Rogers will both be testifying.   Watch live at 10 AM ET here:
Live coverage: FBI director testifies to Congress #Russia

Today was the first of what I hope will be many open hearings on Russia. The American people deserve to know how dangerous Putin’s Russia can be. My line of questioning sought to determine if he attempted to infiltrate the Republican Party to increase support for his armed invasion of Ukraine. This is not a matter of politics but a concern for the integrity of major parts of our government.
Have questions about the #Russia investigation? Congressman Carson is going to take your questions during a Facebook Live Q & A today at 3 PM. Post your questions in the comment section below.

Yesterday I met with President Trump to talk about issues affecting the African-American community. I spoke with him about the importance of ending racial profiling, strengthening the relationship between communities and law enforcement and the alarming ramifications that could result from another #MuslimBan.
Thanks to everyone who called, emailed, and made your voices heard in the debate over #TRUMPCARE. Your voices have been heard. #KilltheBill

Today I toured the Indianapolis Fire Department. Our firefighters put their lives on the line each and every day to keep our community safe, but it can come at a price. Firefighters suffer from several cancers at a statistically higher rate than that of the general population. That's why I'm proud co-sponsor the Firefighter Cancer Registry Act of 2017 which lays the groundwork for investigation, research, and ultimately a reinvention of protective protocol for firefighters.

Today is Equal Pay Day. It has been 54 years since the Equal Pay Act was signed into law, yet women still earn an average of only 80 cents for every dollar earned by men. In Indiana, that gap is even worse. As a cosponsor of the Paycheck Fairness Act, I will continue to support equal pay for equal work. #EqualPayDay

This sign hangs on my door outside my Washington, DC office.  I am a firm believer that rather than looking for ways to keep refugees out we should be discussing how we can strengthen our screening processes while supporting those who are fleeing terrorism and violent oppression.

President Trump's short-sighted budget cuts to NIH and other research agencies are unacceptable. Last week, I demanded more funding for disease research to find cures and treatments to diseases that impact families across the country.  The letter was sent to the Committee on Appropriations requesting increased funding for the National Institutes of Health’s (NIH) research into diseases that affect millions of Americans. Dozens of my colleagues signed on.   Read the full letter: https://newdemocratcoalition-himes.house.gov/media-center/press-releases/new-democrat-coalition-members-demand-more-funding-for-disease-research

With Memorial Day on the horizon, this week I was proud to introduce legislation recognizing today and every Friday before Memorial Day as National Poppy Day. The American Legion and many of America’s overseas partners have long recognized the red poppy flower as a symbol to remember the fallen and support the living heroes who have served in uniform. National Poppy Day encourages all Americans to wear a poppy and join this long tradition of remembrance.

Today we remember all those who gave their lives to protect our future and the freedoms we hold dear. Thank you! #MemorialDay

Like all parents, I have always wanted my daughter to live in a world that is safer and healthier than the one I grew up in. Growing up hearing about acid rain and global warming, I knew this was not a certainty. But I have been heartened that people of all political persuasions have been standing up and calling for changes. They have acted at the ballot box, with their pocketbooks and in their personal behaviors to make little small changes that add up to a big difference. The Paris Agreement was one our biggest steps yet, as people around the world finally acknowledged the shared sacrifice necessary to leave a cleaner planet for the for future generations. With his decision to withdraw the United States from this agreement, President Trump is standing alone among international leaders in looking backward rather than forward.   Over the last several decades, the world has seen that a low carbon future is not just about climate. It is about promoting innovative entrepreneurship and creating good paying, green manufacturing and infrastructure jobs. It is about an economy where industry changes but new jobs ensure that no workers are left behind. These are already some of the fastest growing sectors in the country, prompting many of our biggest industrial players to change their tune and invest in cleaner practices. Yet, today President Trump decided to turn his back on this economic growth in favor of a mythical future in which the old ways of doing business prevail, despite all evidence showing around the world. This will do nothing but leave American workers behind as China, Europe and others benefit from the growing green industries.  Despite President Trump’s shortsightedness, I remain committed to leaving my daughter, and children around the world, a cleaner world where they can build prosperous lives for themselves and their families. I stand ready to cities, states, individuals and businesses that choose to act on their own to make this a reality.
It's gun violence awareness month.  Today I participated in two events urging Congress to pass sensible gun reform measures.

Fantastic turnout today for the Interfaith service that kicked off Pride week in Indy! Great to see spiritual leaders from various faith traditions speak on the theme of letting love lead the way. #lovewins

Hateful rhetoric has real consequences. Whether it comes from a tweet, a billboard, or an ad.  Today, I spoke on CNN about harm that has come from President Trump's bigoted tweets and proposed travel ban in my hometown of Indianapolis.
Need help with a federal agency? Come to my office hours TOMORROW (Wednesday) and get assistance with Medicare & Medicaid, veterans benefits, passports & more.

Today I voted against the Financial 'CHOICE' Act in Congress. This bill is nothing more than a misguided attempt to take us back to a marketplace where big banks were permitted to engage in reckless and unfair activities, leaving consumers at risk.   Wall Street Reform has improved accountability in the financial system and protected consumers, investors and the economy from abusive practices. We should be protecting and strengthening it, not tearing it apart.

Today, Islamophobic rallies are being held across the country, including here in Indianapolis. Today’s rally is an attempt to paint all Muslims as dangerous and un-American, despite generations of evidence pointing to peaceful coexistence and valuable contribution to our society. It saddens me that this rally is being held in our great city, which prides itself for its tolerance and acceptance of differences. Now, more than ever, we must come together and support one another from viewpoints and groups that seek to divide us. #CounterACTHate

One year ago today we lost 49 innocent people in a senseless act of hate and violence. Today, let’s remember the victims of the Pulse shooting, pray for their loved ones, and recommit ourselves to standing up to intolerance in all its forms.

Today I spoke at the 6th annual Intelligence Community Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender, and Allies (IC LGBTA) Summit,  on the importance of bringing together and increasing diversity across the Intelligence Community. #ICPride #LoveisLove
Great night at the Congressional Baseball Game with my staff. We continue to pray for Rep. Scalise, the Capitol Police, and the staff members who were injured on Wednesday.

One of the greatest honors is to present long-overdue medals to veterans of our military. Recently, my office presented Gerry Brannon with several medals that his late father earned during WWII, but never received. My office is always happy to assist veterans and their families with locating discharge paperwork, military records, and service medals.
Happy Father's Day to all the dads out there. Being a dad to my daughter continues to be my most important job.

“If that little store closes, it’s going to be catastrophic.”  Across America’s heartland, more and more grocery stores are closing their doors creating food deserts in rural towns and big cities alike. These closures, are why I recently re-introduced the Food Deserts Act. This bill creates new avenues to fund grocery stores in underserved communities by facilitating low interest loans for new and existing grocery stores in food deserts.

For 52 years, Medicare and Medicaid have provided an essential lifeline to seniors, struggling families and the disabled. As we wish Medicare and Medicaid a very happy birthday, I will keep fighting to provide every single American access to high quality and lifesaving healthcare. Because, as we all know, health care is not a privilege – it is a human right.

Do you or someone you know want to attend one of our nation's service academies? Each year, I have the honor of nominating young men and women from the 7th Congressional District, to our nation’s four Service Academies: the U.S. Military Academy at West Point, the U.S. Naval Academy, the U.S. Air Force Academy, and the U.S. Merchant Marine Academy.  To learn more about how to serve our country and receive a top notch education visit my website-> carson.house.gov/help-from-andre/military-academy-nominations/military-academy-nominations-faq  The application deadline for nominations is October 15th.

Yesterday, President Trump doubled down on his racism and bigotry by issuing an updated Muslim ban. I stood in strong opposition to the last ban and I oppose this one just as strongly. It’s driven by the same discrimination, fear, and ignorance as the first.   Today, the Supreme Court cancelled its hearing on President Trump’s first Muslim ban. I have no doubt that after further review the court will not be fooled by the addition of non-Muslim countries. Like the previous versions, this repackaged ban will primarily block travelers from Muslim countries, as the President seeks to make good on his discriminatory campaign promises. It’s intent, like President Trump’s promises, are clear.  This is not who we are as a country.  I stand by my initial concerns and remain hopeful that the rule of law will prevail.
Today is National Voter Registration Day. Learn more and make sure you are registered to vote at NationalVoterRegistrationDay.org.

On September 30th, several important federal programs will simply run out of money or expire. Among these are programs like the Children’s Health Insurance Program (CHIP), which serves 115,000 Hoosier children, funding for Community Health Centers, which serves over 473,000 patients across Indiana, Perkins Loans for low-income students, funding for safety-net hospitals, and the Home Visiting program, which provides home visits to families in at-risk communities.  These programs have been bipartisan in the past, but unfortunately gridlock in Washington is hurting patients, students, and families. Congress must extend these programs now!

Since the Affordable Care Act took effect, the uninsured rate has been nearly cut in half. The law has brought quality, affordable coverage to millions of Americans, including thousands of Hoosiers. This morning I joined officials at Raphael Health Center to help kick off Open Enrollment for 2018. For more information go to www.healthcare.gov

H.Res. 630 passed the House today, it requires Members of Congress and staff to complete mandatory sexual harassment training. I supported this resolution and I'm happy to see it pass. Every person, woman or man, deserves to work in a place free from harassment and discrimination. This is an important and necessary step forward to hold Congress to the highest of standards.

Today is World AIDS Day, a day to remember those we have lost, and those still struggling with HIV/AIDS. It is also a day to renew our commitment to ending this pandemic in Indianapolis, the United States and around the world.

I was honored to deliver the commencement address to the graduating class at the University of Indianapolis this morning. I am excited to see the contributions these remarkable men & women make going forward!

Our country is in dire need of a modern tax code. But more than that, we need a tax code that supports those who work hard every day and still struggle to get by. This bill does the opposite, which is why I voted against it in the House.
